subject: Re: Avoiding IllegalAccessException
msgSnippet: Two solutions that are basically the same: 1) In the JUnit-addons http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons package there is a PrivateAccessor utility that
messageBody:
Two solutions that are basically the same:

1) In the JUnit-addons http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons
package there is a PrivateAccessor utility that comes in very handy
for doing this sort of thing.

2) Overcome the IllegalAccessException yourself by using
setAccessible(true) (that's what PrivateAccessor does):

Field[] fields = object1.getClass().getDeclaredFields();
Field field = fields[i];
field.setAccessible(true);
Object fieldValue1 = field.get(object2);

Without the setAccessible(true), this results in an exception, but
with it, it works fine.

-joel shellman


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "haefeleuser" <haefeleuser@y...> wrote:
> In my testing class I use reflection to test the class under test.
>
> This works fine as long as testing class and class under test are in
> the same package. Otherwise IllegalAccessException occure which make
> my test results red.
>
> The Javadoc 1.3 says that this is because the two classes are not in
> the same package.
>
> But in the company we put all tests in a sub package named "test".
>
> Does anyone had such a problem before and know a solution? I mean a
> solution where the two classes are in different packages.
>
> Maybe there is an easy solution for it.
